newsitem.title: USA: Dell to enter workstation market this year.
newsitem.headline: Dell to enter workstation market this year.

text.p: Dell Computer Corp. said Wednesday it plans to enter the workstation computer market later this year with systems running Intel Corp.'s Pentium II and Microsoft Corp.'s Windows NT software.
Dell also said it has created an internal unit focused on the workstation business.

The initial workstations -- computers more powerful than conventional personal computers -- will be aimed at financial services, software development and mechanical computer-assisted design and computer-assisted engineering graphics markets.
Dell said it would enter the workstation market at a Goldman Sach Technology Conference in February. At the time, it did not give any further details.

"Dell workstations using one or more Intel processors will save users thousands of dollars at the time of purchase over dedicated Unix-based workstation systems," company Chairman Michael Dell said in a statement. Unix, like Windows NT, is a computer operating system.

Dell said the workstation market will probably follow a similar pattern to the network server, or computer, business, where systems running the Unix operating system are often replaced by powerful but less expensive servers running Windows NT.
Dell stock rose $1 to $83.75 on the Nasdaq, setting a new high for the year.
